threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Welcome to /diy/, a place to:

Post and discuss /diy/ projects, ask questions regarding /diy/ topics and exchange ideas and techniques.

Please keep in mind:
- This is a SFW board. No fleshlights or other sex toys.
- No weapons. That goes to /k/ - Weapons. The workmanship and techniques involved in creating objects which could be used as weapons or the portion of a weapons project that involves them (e.g., forging steel for a blade, machining for gunsmithing, what epoxy can I use to fix my bow) may be discussed in /diy/, but discussing weapon-specific techniques/designs or the actual use of weapons is disallowed. Things such as fixed blade knives or axes are considered tools, things such as swords, guns or explosives are considered weapons.
- No drugs or drug paraphernalia (See Global Rule 1). If you want to discuss something that could involve such things (e.g., carving a tobacco pipe from wood) that's fine, but make sure it's /diy/ related and doesn't involve drugs or it will result in deletion/ban.

Helpful links:
https://sites.google.com/site/diyelmo/
http://www.engineeringtoolbox.com/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Some friendly suggestions for posting:
- First ask Google, then ask /diy/. Your question will probably be better received if you do so.
- List available resources (tools, materials, budget, time, etc.)
- Try to use pictures and explain the goal, if possible
- Be patient, this is a slow board; your thread will be around for days.
- Share your results! /diy/ loves to see problems solved and projects completed!

last_replies.name: Anonymous

While I doubt too many here will create/use composting toilets anyway I feel it must be said that it's not a great idea to use peat because it's pretty damaging to the environment to harvest.
It takes decades to grow back.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507259
>most people just dump it as soon as the trip is over

If your camping trips are short enough term that you'll be back home or near facilities before the composting is complete then a composter doesn't make much sense when you can get picrel for around $150 (or less for one with a smaller holding tank).
That one does 50 flushes per cycle and dumps in a regular toilet or regular RV dumpout, and you can extend the time to dumpout by peeing in a bush when possible and laying a couple of sheets of TP in it before taking a crap to minimize the amount of flush water needed per use, possibly even eliminate it (no pun intended). You can also put a grocery bag in it and toss that if you want to take advantage of a dumpster to extend the cycle.
A capful of the blue chemical after each emptying keeps them free of bad odors and with a bit of care two normal adults can easily manage two weeks between emptying.
We used one for five years full timing and never had a problem with the unit mechanically, with odors, or with dumping it at a gas station or park/campground bathroom.

There are a few days where it's below freezing during the daytime but not many.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506771
Up here in the north sap seems to run in the fall anytime the temps fall below freezing at night and the tree gets warm enough during the day and goes until things stay below freezing for awhile. You can tap any maple, not just sugar maple, the others just have a lower sugar content so produce less syrup for the amount of sap. If memory serves birch's run when it is a bit warmer and you may get a better yield from them in your area but it has been years since I have done this. Birch syrup is tasty, as is birch beer.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506619
I know a thing or two about making syrup.
The only reason they say you want warmer temps during the day is so the sap actually flows. If it's warm enough, it'll run almost like turning on your kitchen faucet. (Depending on the size of the tree.) If it's super cold, it'll still flow, it just takes a day or two to fill a bucket.
That's why people who do it seriously tap 5-10-20 trees at a time. Also because of the sheer volume of the sap that you need.
Ballpark figures are 1 5gal bucket of maple sap will give you ~1pt of pure syrup when reduced. Maybe a little more, maybe a little less. That 250ml bottle in your pic is a shade over 1 cup. That's half a pint. It took ~2.5 gals of sap to make that much syrup.
If you have any other questions, feel free to ask. I'm no expert, but I'll tell you what I can.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505792
>the edges of your jacket are all sewn together
Yes, but then there's a strip of "seam sealing tape" applied over the stitches, to cover the stitch holes. Looks like this pic.

>>2505657
>afraid that sewing would screw up the goretex membrane
It will. Even if you use the smallest possible needle, and non-wicking thread, water will still get in. Those membranes only function when they're contiguous.

>old windbreaker jacket (100% polyester)
There's different kinds of Goretex. Most is 3 layer (outer fabric, goretex middle, liner fabric), some is 2 layer (outer, goretex, no liner). Are you saying your jacket has a polyester shell, or liner?
Anyway, I would recommend sewing the loop to your jacket, and then seam taping.
If you're doing a line on the back panel, that would be easy. Something like an arm patch/armband would be much more fiddly (I'm thinking about reflective elements on something like a cycling jacket).

Most tapes are heat-sensitive, Melco is a common brand. It's kind of a pain to iron the stuff on, because it's so easy to melt synthetic fabrics while you're setting the tape. The proper tool for it is a tiny iron, they look more like soldering irons (look up "electric leather iron", and Clover makes one too). If you use a normal household iron, you'll only be using the inch or half inch at the very tip, and it's more work to maneuver. It wouldn't be too bad on a broad, flat piece of fabric though.

I'd recommend the pressure-sensitive kind if you can find some. Usually they are marketed as material specific (tape for X fabric, tape for Y fabric). Just make sure the fabric is clean, and press it on with a thumb/felt pad. RBTR sells a "dyneema repair tape" that sticks quite well to other fabrics too. I've had strips stuck to the polyester liner of some Xpac since 2018, no peeling, no leaks.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2506358
drywaller here, agreeing with the Toggle bolt idea. If the whole railing came off, and each end has 3 screw holes, then get 6 toggle bolts.
If this were me, I'd tear out the 3 holes until I had a good sized hole to see what was behind the concrete/cement.
If it's hollow less than 3 or 3 1/2 in, then you could use a regular aluminum stud ( !___! )
with this profile (looking down the 4-8ft ones at a retail store), buy the stud, take it home and cut off pieces about 6-8 inches long.
Then take 4 screws long enough to reach the stud, place the stud in the hollow gap vertical (up and down) with the middle part of the stud where you want to rescrew the 3 holes for the railing. Drill 2 screws at the top of the stud and 2 at the bottom so the aluminum stud is secured to the wall (FIRST) before doing anything with the railing.
go to a retail hardware store and buy this
(its a Home Depot product but this comes in other brands in other stores)
https://www.homedepot.com/p/Sika-1-Gal-Ready-Mix-Concrete-Patch-and-Repair-Textured-Concrete-Patch-7116140/300934581
This is a lot to read. I'll keep an eye on this thread. Please let us know if it is hollow or not further into the wall. I can guide you on the rest of the steps but this is a very visual process I'm describing.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505003
That's a reasonable approach and while the 12/12 thing is kind of arbitrary and perhaps not optimal, learning why and what might work better *for you* is valuable in and of itself, and probably won't take a full year and hindsight to be revealed.
Otherwise as long as you are realistic in your expectations there's nothing wrong with this approach and plenty of professional skills are taught in 4 week courses (or less) that are adequate for the academic portion of becoming certified. You have to be really focused to do it that way, but the point is that there's all kinds of skills that can be picked up in a short time and then built upon further if you want to master them.
You can learn to scuba dive and get certified in under a week and there are accelerated flight training schools where people get a pilots license in 2- weeks...it's not easy but it's possible so don't listen to people whose first response is to discourage you from your plan.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Cooking is probably the most useful skill to start with. You won't become a master in a month, but that's okay because you will probably practice it every day for the rest of your life. Don't forget to check if your kitchen fire extinguisher is good.
Then based on your limits, maybe a 3d printer. You will be able to learn about materials, design, and modeling.
Hand sewing can be useful to repair small tears and also save someones life in an emergency. A bit of thread and a needle is cheap too.
Actually go take a first aid course or get CPR certified while were on the subject, and put this near the top of your list just in case.
If you can't swim, find swimming lessons. Your skills won't do you good if you randomly drown.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In construction and I have done some insulation before.

If there is a noticeable difference it sounds like your insulation job on round 2 was not as good as round 1.

There are a lot of crevices, spots, corners and seams that need a proper fitting piece of insulation. And if everything is done like a glove the inside area will hold heat like an oven. If lots of spots were missed, especially close to the perimeter of the home, then the heat is running right out.

Might be worth going up there with some gloves and pulling back some insulation to see if they got all the corners and joists and stuff.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2507045
Veg tan is the way to go, thickness depends entirely on what you are making. You're not going to make a good wallet out of the thick stuff, and you can't make a good belt out of the thin stuff.

I don't think it matters in the long run what thickness you learn on. If you stick with the hobby for more than a couple projects, you'll just end up getting another kind of leather anyway.

I do recommend getting a whole hide (or a side) if you plan on doing belts. Cows seem real big until you try and find 40 continuous inches in a straight line.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Has anyone here made /diy/ a "career"? In a sense that you make money/run a business with your diy knowledge/craft? I'm tired of my wagie office job. I can't handle anymore staring at a screen so much.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Was a software engineer/systems analyst for about 15 years before starting a 1-person handyman business. Was good at fixing my own shit, found that I could make money fixing other people's shit, too. I enjoyed the problem-solving aspect of it (like my previous career,) got bored with some of the more mundane jobs. It was also nice being able to write off tools and equipment on my taxes.

I launched my business with a targeted postcard campaign, positioning myself as a knowledgeable DIYer who lived in the same community and was somebody like your neighbors and co-workers. I'm in an affluent suburb, so many people really liked dealing with me, versus some crusty old drunk who smelled like cigarettes and BO, or someone who didn't speak English very well.

Did it for about 12 years. By the end, I was charging around $70/hr and had all the work I could handle. But it's a grind to get in enough billable hours during a week to really make great money. Even though I was just a schmuck-in-a-truck, there's overhead ($1M liability policy, business licenses, supplies, transportation etc.) and it's not always possible to consistently log 6-8 hours per day, 5-6 days per week. I always told people who asked, "This job isn't paying my mortgage." My wife has a lucrative career that carried most of major expenses.

But the physical toll finally got to be too much. Moving from a desk job to something that physical, I wasn't really ready for it. After 12 years, I had developed arthritis in both thumbs that made many jobs very painful. As I got into my 50s, I was less comfortable on high ladders, and just kind of got tired of the whole grind.

Someone stronger, with more stamina, and a higher pain threshold could do well, though. If you're halfway careful about what you do, stick to things you know are within your skills, take the time to research fixes, and don't cheap out on materials and tools, you'll soon have a list of people clamoring for your services.

Just not down to very narrow beads or on very thin stock due to filler wire size limitations. MIG cannot do autogeneous welding which comes in quite handy once you know about it.

last_replies.name: Anonymous

>>2505570
>You have...the ability to genuinely deep dive into anything and become a master at it.

What you don't acknowledge is that most people working in any trade or field aren't anywhere near being "masters" and don't need to be to do competent work. Often the people in top positions have very narrow and limited skill sets, and the more technical the work is the more likely they are to have extremely specialized capabilities.
In fields that require a broad range of skills and knowledge to be competent there are often concessions made in applying training resources based on the chance of encountering certain problems, so that it's often possible to literally have more education from a week perusing the internet than a licensed doctor or lawyer gets about certain rare situations that were barely mentioned on one or two pages in his school textbooks 15 years ago.
Building contractors in particular often know little more than how to pass a test and write contracts, which is all that most GC license schools focus on.
The ones who can actually speak authoritatively about actual construction gained that knowledge from working at all the different jobs involved, not shunning them.
Strong work teams that are adaptable and deal with fast paced critical situations make a point of having all the team members work at the various positions involved just to understand what is involved and so they can sub for each other in emergencies enough that they operation can at least limp along instead of being dead in the water..
That kind of thing is common in everything from retail stores to fabrication shops to boat crews to the military.

Also there's no guarantee that whatever you take a "deep dive" into will be around when you are even halfway to mastering it, and to stay employed you may need to take a hard turn from something like switchboard operator or typesetter or VCR repair tech into a new paradigm that renders much of your mastery and esoteric knowledge useless.

As a note, those cook-tops are usually very straightforward to replace, and often inexpensive.

I shattered one while living in a condo, took me less than 24hrs to find a brand-new replacement in town and install it myself; it was ~$100 for the whole top unit.
Since then, I've done two others for friends, and the story is the same, they run 10%-15% the price of the whole stove, not bad.
Those were glass-top electric stoves, not quite the same, OP does appear to have an induction cook-top.
Still an easy job, just not as cheap, it's not unusual to pay 25%-50% the price of the stove for a replacement top.

It's a no-brainer when it's $80 and 20 minutes of work to make it basically new again, but it may be more of a debate when it's $300+.
Look into it for your model, it might be cheap enough to consider.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502388
Depends on the climate and environment. If your country or county is rich in cob, it's a cheap material and depending on the way it's built, it can be easier to build alone than laying bricks. The best climate is if you live in a normal or dryer climate.
As methods, you can look up example traditional hungarian cob houses. They used (sometimes not) woven net as basic wall structure, and layer by layer plastered cob on it. They made half meter thickness usually. The positive side to it that summer was always cool inside and the air quality is top notch, never dry, and with the good lime plaster it never gets wet. Bad side is that they had to make huge roof over hanger to avoid wetness from rain. They painted the wall yearly again as protection.
An other, more geometrical method: Look up japanese cob wall installations. They build it wall by wall or panel by panel where they use a wire mesh so it holds the cob and gives more flexibility to the walls, but the weight holding structure is wood there.

I've jerry-rigged a 420 w-h autonomous power supply, using off the shelf parts. It seems to work, but how could I improve it's safety? I will post more info in the thread.

I live in Ukraine and we're having outages every day for 4 hours twice a day, sometimes more often, so I was thinking about using this device for lighing and charging my devices. Maybe I would run PC from it, but not for long.

Wasnt sure if this should be a separate thread, if not, I'm sorry

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2505235
As long as you're only using 150-200W loads, that is probably fine. Beyond that, the battery wires (the blue/brown ones) are way too thin, the connectors are too small. You should fuse each battery's output right at the terminal with maybe 15A fuses. Saw the battery board in two, coat the surface in thick blob of solder and isolate + and - (wrap them in tape or heatshrink or something).
If you had some money to put into it, EASUN has very cheap ~200 euro 12V-24V solar inverters that have everything included, the option of connecting solar panels to charge the battery, also direct UPS switching and battery management.

All the info you need about 3D-printing: https://pastebin.com/AKqpcyN5
>Your print failed? Go to:
https://www.simplify3d.com/support/print-quality-troubleshooting/

If that doesn't help you solve your print problems, please post:
>A picture of the failed part
>Printer make & model
>Filament type/brand
>Slicer & slicer settings

>What printer should I buy? [Last updated 12-20-2021]
Under 250 USD: kingroon KP3L, Sovol sv01, Creality Ender 3 (v2), Anycubic Mega S
Under 500 USD: Qidi X-One2, Creality CR-10, Anycubic Vyper, Prusa Mini,
Under 1000 USD: Prusa i3, Flashforge creator pro 2
Over 1000 USD: e3d toolchanger, Ultimaker, Qidi X-CF Pro, Build your own Voron, Prusa XL (lol enjoy the wait)
SLA: Anycubic Photon, Elegoo Mars, Prusa SL1, Formlabs Form 3, Creality HALOT-ONE
Instead of buying a new printer, you could consider building your own: https://reprap.org/wiki/

>Where can I get free things to print?
https://www.thingiverse.com/
https://thangs.com/
https://grabcad.com/
https://google.com/
https://printables.com/
https://www.yeggi.com/

>What CAD software should I use?
Variants of professional parametric CAD programs such as Solidworks (lol paying for software), Fusion360, Inventor, Onshape, TinkerCAD, and AutoCAD may be free depending on your profession, level of piracy and definition of ''free''.
Most anons use Fusion360, but some /g/oobers prefer OpenSCAD or FreeCAD. If you want to do mesh free-forming and modeling, Blender is alright. Also while not necessarily a design program, Meshmixer (free) can be extremely useful for tweaking models to print.

How do you make a Centennial Light Bulb? Googling it obviously brings up no DIYs for it, but if it was made in the 1890s, then obviously it's possible that you can make one yourself today. The whole reason they were built to be shortlasting is solely because it wasn't good for business (understandable). But I'm fucking tired of changing my lightbulbs just for them to blow after like a week.

Does anyone know the "archaic knowledge that was lost to time" required to make one?

Here's a video on it:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZLhe9tD6f98

And the Wikipedia:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centennial_Light

There's no mention on how it works, and the video itself says they're having to "study it" to find out how exactly it does. I'm not exactly looking for an exact replication, but even a light-bulb that lasts a fraction of the time this one has would be fucking awesome.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502549
Get a standard LED bulb and put in a resistor to run it very very underpowered. It will last essentially forever

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2502549
>Does anyone know the "archaic knowledge that was lost to time" required to make one?

Here is how you can make LED bulbs which last forever:
https://www.fingers-welt.de/phpBB/viewtopic.php?f=14&t=19109&p=418276#p418276

The trick is basically to lower the power output considerably so that the LEDs do not overheat. This way, you can make them last forever.

If you really want to use incandescent bulbs:
- buy 230V bulbs and run them on 110V
- Put a diode in one cable of the two connected to the bulb.
This will lower their output and increase the lifespan.

a common failure point in led lights is the driver, not the leds...you are going to want to use high quality components for the power supply, or maybe have like 5 drivers in there, each driving alternating leds? that way, when 1 set fails, the other 4 will still run! its like having 5 light bulbs in one!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2504426
YW. For glass that's hazy/foggy from abrasion and pitting you might try applying a wax product made especially for glass, picrel is the old school standard that isn't made anymore but there are similar products that go on like car wax and buff off that can really help rejuvenate the shine and fill microscopic damage that makes the surface appear cloudy.

FWIW, if you have been quoted
$400 for 96"×30"×1/4" beveled glass that's a pretty good price...personally for a case top I'd go at least 5/16" if it's just annealed glass and it could be made to fit.
Thing is though that glass prices are exponential as it gets thicker so you can't count on 125% thicker only going up that much, it might be $600 (150%) instead.

All that said, the dirtyxsecret about glass fabrication and sales is that you can pay practically anything for any size/thickness or edge treatment, tempering, etc....there's no real industry pricing standards and shipping/handling and risk of breakage are how costs are figured, the material itself isxtge least of it. Busy shops and larger operators can usually spread those costs out so always get multiple quotes from a bunch of shops...in my experience the best price on mirror, or tempered glass, or dual glazing, or decorative edgework or textured and specialty glass will almost never be from the same place, everyone has loss leaders and has other stuff at a premium.
It's like buying meat, prices are all over the place and the cheap supermarket may charge more than a real butcher on one thing while the butcher charges 10× as much for something else.

threads.sub: Replacing my 12v car battery with 18650s without a BMS
threads.com:
We all know charging 18650s above 4.2v is bad.

Lets say my car alternator charges the lead acid battery to 14v.

If I parallel 4 x 18650 at 4.2v the maximum safe voltage would be 16.8v. This is above the max voltage the alternator outputs, which is 14v.

So at 14v each 18650 cell would be at only 3.5v, and I don't have to worry about overcharging since once the 18650s are at 14v they simply won't accept any more current since the voltage isn't rising.

Now if I add multiple parallel banks of 4 x 18650s I would have each cell at 3.5v but lot of available current, enough to start a car.

So doing it this way, I figure I don't need a BMS since there is no way the 18650s can be overcharged. Tell me if I am wrong?

>the issue is that my inverter will have a maximum output power of 5kW, meaning I can't connect 10kW of solar panels to it as far as in know
That's not how electricity works. Your inverter will use the amount of power it needs to use even if the panels are able to provide more.

Think of an electrical device as a vaccuum rather than thinking of the electrical supply as a pump. The panels aren't forcing electricity into the inverter, the inverter is pulling electricity from the panels. And it will only pull as much as it's going to use.

>Inverters are rated to peak voltage and amps
Most inverters (with the noteable exception of Victron) do NOT have an input current limit; they are normally rated with an output current spec. Even with the Victron units, they will safely operate on a huge current source, but it's possible under certain failure conditions that they would blow their input fuse. Thus still failing safely.

Could be insulation failing on old wires, pulling the wire to replace switch can sometimes cause insulation to fail where you can not see it (outside the box in the wall) or it can cause damaged wire to finally short. Very unlikely that replacing that switch is not related, timing is just too perfect. This will probably be a job for a proper electrician and make sure to tell him about replacing that switch.

Found the solution - there was a singular outside light that was hooked up the the interior lights circuit. One of my wisterias outside broke a drain pipe by growing and creeping, and the drain pipe break happened to be right above that outdoor light. Outdoor light filled up with water and caused an earth fault.

Thank you all for your replies.

DCF891 is the new one, DCF894 is the older version. They look pretty much identical but I think the 891 is like a 30% power jump.

Supposedly the new 891 is almost as powerful as their older 899 high torque 1/2”, and it’s quite compact, so that thing will be great for weekend warrior automotive and should rattle loose almost all of the fasteners you run into on a passenger car.

But yeah, don’t fall for the people who own a 12V stubby and say “It removed my Honda lug nuts, it’s all you need!”… put lugs on and torque then to 80-100ft-lbs and your impact driver with a socket adapter could get it off after some rattling. Wait for that Honda to come back from a tire shop that used air tools or put on the summer tires after a winter of salty roads and the compact stuff will really struggle.

Those people tried to get an impact wrench for as cheap as possible and have never touched any of the 600ft-lb+ breakaway rated mid torque 1/2” guns so they have no comparison.
